The role of the eze Nri is not complete until the journey to the sacred Anambra River has taken place. There, the eze Nri must demonstrate their blessing by collecting stones from beneath the water, before being buried, exhumed, and anointed in white clay. The Ìkénga are our eyes and ears; we do not mingle with our followers. Instead, we must rule through our Ìkénga: those priests and noblemen who adminster the day-to-day running of the empire. But we believe that the Ìkénga are too disconnected from the role of their sacred eze Nri.
